bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

keywords.term: on special wounds and injuries of the head
wounds and injuries of the head
gunshot contusions of the cranial bones
contusion of the skull without fracture
such lesions of brain as led to insanity
wound in parietal region by conoidal musket ball, denuding bone of periosteum

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, edited and added keyword terms
additional proofing of transcription and encoding
case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: ELLIOTT, ESTES E., Private, Co. G, 36th Massachusetts Volunteers, aged 21 years, received, at the battle of Cold Harbor, Virginia, June 3d, 1864, a wound in the left parietal region, denuding the bone of its periosteum, by a conoidal musket ball. He was admitted into the field hospital of the 3d division, Ninth Corps, and, a few days later, sent to Washington, and admitted into the Carver Hospital. Simple dressings were used. He died from concussion of the brain, June 23d, 1864.
